description: The Chimera stands as one of Greek mythology's most terrifying and symbolically rich monsters, a fire-breathing hybrid creature combining lion, goat, and serpent into a single fearsome form. According to Homer and Hesiod, she was the offspring of the primordial monsters Typhon and Echidna, making her sibling to other legendary beasts including Cerberus, the Hydra, and the Sphinx. The Chimera ravaged the kingdom of Lycia in Asia Minor, devastating crops with her flames and slaughtering livestock and humans alike, until the hero Bellerophon was sent to destroy her. Mounted on the divine winged horse Pegasus, Bellerophon attacked from above where the Chimera's triple nature could not reach him, finally killing her by thrusting a lead-tipped spear into her mouth where the fire melted the lead, choking the beast. The Chimera's form - lioness in front, goat in the middle, serpent behind - has been interpreted variously as representing a volcanic mountain, the three seasons, or the combination of base instincts. Her name became the English word 'chimera' for any impossible fantasy or hybrid creation, testament to her enduring impact on Western imagination.

physicalDescription: A monstrous creature with the head and front body of a lion, a second goat head rising from her back, and a living serpent for a tail. Some accounts describe her as having three heads on one body, others as a lion-goat-serpent fusion. The goat head breathed fire. She was large enough to devastate entire regions.

sections.origins: The Chimera was born from Typhon, the most terrible of all monsters who once challenged Zeus himself, and Echidna, the 'Mother of All Monsters' who was half beautiful woman and half serpent. This fearsome parentage made the Chimera sibling to many of Greek mythology's most famous monsters. She established herself in Lycia (southwestern Turkey), where Mount Chimaera (modern Yanartas) still produces natural gas flames - likely the geological origin of the fire-breathing legend. King Iobates of Lycia, wanting to dispose of the hero Bellerophon, sent him against the Chimera expecting his death.
sections.attributes: The Chimera's triple nature was unique even among mythological hybrids. The lion represented savage strength and kingly ferocity, the goat (sometimes depicted as emerging from her back) provided the fire-breathing ability associated with its volcanic home, and the serpent tail added venomous danger and represented chthonic powers. This combination made her nearly invincible to conventional attack. Her fire devastated the Lycian landscape, and no warrior could approach her directly.
sections.significance: The Chimera represents the ultimate hybrid monster in Greek thought - not merely a mixing of species but a violation of natural categories that creates something more terrifying than any single beast. Her existence posed a challenge to cosmic order (kosmos) that required heroic intervention. The myth also explains the volcanic phenomena of Lycia and demonstrates the hero's need for divine assistance (Pegasus, given by Poseidon or Athena) to overcome supernatural evil.
sections.impact: The Chimera gave her name to the scientific and common term 'chimera' - any organism or concept combining disparate elements. In genetics, a chimera is an organism with cells from multiple zygotes. In art and architecture, chimeras appear throughout Western decorative tradition, from Greek pottery to medieval cathedral gargoyles. The concept of chimeric combination influences modern fantasy and science fiction. Her defeat by Bellerophon established the template of the aerial monster-slaying hero that echoes through St. George and countless dragon-slayers.
